chapter_mapping.note: Act II alternates historical chapters with Lilith contemporary chapters

thematic_question.central: Can enlightenment be achieved through helping others, or must the helper-identity itself be released?
secondary: What is the relationship between love and attachment?
Can two beings compete for transcendence, or is competition itself an obstacle?
What persists when the self is illusion?
thematic_question.resolution: The competition was illusory. Silas and Lilith were always two aspects of the same future Buddha—Maitreya. Their apparent opposition was the necessary friction through which that Buddha-to-be developed.

maitreya_resolution.description: In Chapter 26, Silas and Lilith's consciousnesses merge to become Maitreya, the future Buddha prophesied in Buddhist texts.
maitreya_resolution.meaning: The 'one Buddha per world-system' rule was true but misunderstood. There was only ever one Buddha-to-be, appearing as two until ready to unite.
foreshadowing_needed: References to Maitreya throughout the novel
Moments where their separation seems artificial
Times when harming him causes her inexplicable pain
Her attraction to him that exceeds tactical calculation

buddhist_context.maitreya: The prophesied future Buddha who will appear when the dharma has been forgotten
buddhist_context.one_buddha_rule: Only one Sammasambuddha can exist in a world-system at a time
buddhist_context.other_buddhas: Amitabha and others exist in different world-systems, referenced to establish cosmology
